rsbNotes.title: Heb 9:1
rsbNotes.text: 9:1 worship . . . holiness. This verse begins a lengthy comparison of Old Testament sacrifice and the sacrifice of Christ, that continues into ch. 10. The first part is a summary of the Old Testament sanctuary and its activities.

rsbNotes.title: Heb 9:3
rsbNotes.text: 9:3 curtain. This curtain, or veil closed off the Most Holy Place, where God’s presence among His people was most intensely revealed (6:19). With Jesus’ death, this curtain was torn in two (10:20; Matt. 27:51).

rsbNotes.title: Heb 9:4
rsbNotes.text:
9:4 golden altar of incense. Although this incense altar, was just outside the curtain (Ex. 40:26), its function was so closely associated with the inner chamber and the ark therein (Ex. 30:6) that it was considered to belong there (1 Kin. 6:22). When the high priest entered the Most Holy Place, he burned incense, producing smoke to hide the mercy seat on top of the ark of the Testimony, shielding himself from the Lord’s burning purity (Lev. 16:12, 13).

Aaron’s staff. The staff that budded to show that priestly privilege comes only by God’s appointment (Num. 17:10), as taught in 5:4, 5.

rsbNotes.title: Heb 9:5
rsbNotes.text:
9:5 cherubim of glory. The “mercy seat,” comprising the lid of the ark, had on it two figures of cherubim facing each other, representative of God’s heavenly courtiers, who serve constantly in His presence.

Of these things . . . cannot now speak in detail. First-century Jewish writers such as Philo gave great attention to the symbolism of the sanctuary furniture. The author of Hebrews, however, desires to address what took place in the tabernacle, and he says no more about the furniture, whatever symbolic value it might have.

rsbNotes.title: Heb 9:6
rsbNotes.text: 9:6 priests go regularly into the first section. Their task was to replace the showbread (Ex. 25:30; Lev. 24:5–9), to keep the lampstand burning (Ex. 27:20, 21; Lev. 24:1–4), and to burn fragrant incense twice daily, symbolizing the people’s prayers (Ex. 30:7–9; Luke 1:8–10; Rev. 8:3).

rsbNotes.title: Heb 9:7–8
rsbNotes.text: 9:7, 8 That only one person, once a year, and only with special preparation, could enter the Most Holy Place, was the Holy Spirit’s revelation through the law that the earthly sanctuary could not be the means of open, confident approach to God. The new covenant promise, “they shall all know me” (8:11), could not be fulfilled in the earthly tent.

rsbNotes.title: Heb 9:7
rsbNotes.text:
9:7 for himself. Levitical priests were themselves in need of atonement, unlike our High Priest, Jesus (5:3; 7:26, 27).

unintentional. See note 5:2.

rsbNotes.title: Heb 9:9
rsbNotes.text: 9:9 symbolic for the present age. The writer interprets the tabernacle ceremonies as prophetic of the time of the gospel (8:5 note). In this case, the ritual requirements display the weakness that the gospel would overcome.
